An Ontario crackdown on massage parlours continues Canada\'s legacy of anti- racism.  The  conversation.   canadas-legacy-of-anti-asian-racism- Elene Lam PhD candidate, School of Social Work, McMaster University Author Note Elene Lam  This paper draws on research supported by the Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council and Butterfly (Asian and Migrant Sex Workers Support Network). Correspondence concerning this article should be addressed Elene Lam,  Main Street West, Hamilton, ON L8S 4L8. Email: lamy4@mcmaster.ca Note(s): ISSN: X Migrant sex workers in Canada are regulated and affected by a web of laws and policies at the federal, provincial, and municipal levels. This article lays out how these laws and policies, which claim to protect migrant workers, govern and harm their lives. Focusing on the experiences of migrants of Asian descent, this article explores how ill-conceived anti-trafficking laws and enforcement, including sex work-related criminal law, immigration laws that target and prohibit sex work, provincial human trafficking laws, and municipal laws regulating body rub services, conflate sex work with trafficking and further endanger migrant sex workers.Keywords: migrant, immigration, race, racism, sex workers, trafficking, law, legalLes travailleurs migrants de sex workers.Keywords: migrant, immigration, race, racism, sex workers, trafficking, law, legalLes travailleurs migrants de l\'industrie du sexe au Canada sont reglementes et touches par un agencement de lois et de politiques aux niveaux federal, provincial et municipal. Cet article explique comment ces lois et politiques, qui pretendent proteger les travailleurs migrants, regissent et nuisent a leur vie. En se concentrant sur les experiences des migrants d\'origine asiatique, cet article explore comment les lois contre la traite des personnes et leur application mal concues, confondent le travail du sexe avec la traite des personnes et mettent davantage en danger les travailleurs du sexe migrants. En se penchant sur le droit penal lie au travail du sexe, les lois sur l\'immigration qui ciblent et interdisent le travail du sexe, les lois provinciales sur la traite des personnes et les lois municipales reglementant les services de massage corporel.Mots-cles : migrant, immigration, ethnie, racisme, travailleur de l\'industrie du sexe, traite, droit, juridique', ' Christophe LAMFALUSSY. 80 years later, Normandy has been paying tribute since the beginning of the week to the allied soldiers who landed on June 6,  to put an end to the Nazi occupation. Journalist Christophe Lamfalussy looks back on this event which changed the course of history with the testimonies of the first American soldiers parachuted or arrived on the beaches, at the dawn of the D-Day landings. In , as a student at the Graduate School of Journalism at Columbia University, I embarked on a special mission for my master’s thesis. Forty years after D-Day, I wanted to find and interview some of the veterans of that pivotal battle, and get their stories from the very first US soldiers who parachuted onto the fields or landed on the beaches of Normandy. At that time, veterans were mostly retired. I met them in the privacy of the veterans’posts, where they were playing poker and paying for beers consumed by those they’d called their buddies for decades. They were digging through their memories, endlessly arguing about nicknames and abbreviations. Sometimes they had to hush up the oldest, who did not want to stop talking. Apart from their get-togethers, they said, nobody wanted to hear them. Not even their children. They were secretly too proud to speak out. Today, as the 80th anniversary of the invasion rapidly approaches, nearly all of them have passed away. But I want their memories to live. This is their story. They were in their middle twenties, and so proud to be Americans. Some of them had lied about their age, adding three years or subtracting five, just to be admitted in the 1 st US Army, commanded by General Omar Bradley, which would hit the beach or make the great jump --somewhere in France. Of course, they did not know where they were going to fight. The sole clue was a little 36-page pocket guide to France, published by the War and Navy Department and distributed to all troops. “You are about to play a personal part in pushing the Germans out of France” it said. “Whatever part you take — rifleman, hospital orderly, mechanic, pilot, clerk, gunner, truck driver — you will be an essential factor in a great effort.” Normandy, among other regions, was described as the butter, egg, cheese and grazing country, with the richest farms in France and the largest churches. “Normandy looks rather like Ohio,” the booklet maintained. After months of training in the military camps scattered along the south British coastline, reading the pocket guide to France was a kind of anti-climax to the hours of thinking and waiting for H-hour. Besides seriously warning that prostitutes in France could be undercover Nazi agents and that venereal diseases would be “a nasty souvenir of Paris for you to take back home,” the booklet introduced the soldier into the sophisticated French national character. The French shake hands instead of slapping you on the back. They are economical and industrious, but don’t like telling how much money they make. They are churchgoers and rarely get drunk in the cafés — a place where they talk shop, close a deal or talk politics. Most of all, they are good talkers and magnificent cooks “if there still is anything left to put in the pot.” But it was also an introduction to war and to the reasons that led thousands of kids like them to cross the Atlantic Ocean. “The main fact about France’s defeat for you, an American soldier, is that when France fell, the biggest democracy in Europe fell, and with it, whether we all realized it or not, our last defense on the continent against Hitler’s crazy world conquest plan.” “We knew we were going to something terrible” And here they were, far away from their homes, paratroopers of the 82 nd and 101 st Airborne Division and soldiers of the 1 st and 4 th Infantry Divisions. They were part of thousands of Allied Forces under the ground command of British General Sir Bernard Montgomery and the supreme command of US General Dwight D. Eisenhower that would break Hitler’s Fortress Europa. Besides their pride — and perhaps their vanity — they were scared, simply scared, and they thought of H-hour as no more than a way to put an end to these days of wondering, thinking and praying. “We were more or less indoctrinated, knowing that we were going to something terrible,” says David Nelson, then a 22-year-old Private Technician of the 801 Ordnance Unit. “We were afraid. All you can do is do the job and hope that you are going to survive.” This fifth day of June is not one of those landmarks in history to be covered by generalization. It was many things to many men. About 287,000 men and a host of armored equipment had been preloaded into ships, some of them a week previous. Just before embarking, they had got the last tokens of the supply service’s care : seven sticks of chewing gum, emergency rations, insecticide powder, cigarettes, a tin of canned heat, water-purification tablets, chewing tobacco, one razor blade, twelve seasickness pills and two vomit bags. Thousands were on deck, already sick and cold, but relatively fortunate compared to those who were below, crammed in the great caverns of the LCTs (landing craft tanks) and in the narrow quarters of the LSI’s (landing ships, infantry), with no light except from a flickering yellow bulb. For them, landing on the French shores would also mean deliverance and daylight. Jumping into unknown territory Planning the invasion had a lot to do with the weather forecast. By June 4, the weather was so bad that the invasion had to be delayed for one day. On the 5th, though a gusty westerly was still pouring the spume into the faces of those who were staying above deck, conditions were better. As a result, by sunrise, the giant armada of 5,000 ships began to move from their anchorages and reached the coastal waters of Britain. For all who could see it, the evidence was there : D-Day would be June 6. The convoy — a wedge more than 50 miles wide — moved eerily in the buoyed channels cleared by the minesweeping flotillas. Even the evening brought an unexpected break in the weather, and a soldier wrote : “It was a perfect summer’s evening, the Isle of Wight lay green and friendly, and tantalizingly peaceful behind the tapestry of warships.” When, on the same evening, a strident alarm rang in England, paratroopers of the 82nd Airborne Division rushed to the runway, expecting one of those twice-a-day or once-a-night drills that used to finish abruptly. “It must have been 11 : 30 or midnight,” recalls Robert E. Burman, then a Staff Sergeant in the 507 thParachute Infantry Regiment. “The props started to turn again. We thought it was going to be another dry run. We started to move out, and we realized this was it.” Already in the sky, a grim-faced 23-year-old named Schuyler W. Jackson was checking his watch. It was 11 : 30 pm, and Jackson’s C-47 had been circling around England since 9 : 00 pm to allow the whole formation to get together. A demolition man of the 502 nd Parachute Infantry Regiment, Jackson was in the first wave of 23 planes that would drop units of the 101 st Airborne Division in the fields of Normandy. Despite a fractured metatarsus bone in his foot, which had been soothed by a shot of novocaine, he wouldn’t have missed the jump for anything. Like so many others, he was thinking of the powerful words of Maj. Gen. William C. Lee : “The 101 st is a new division. It has no history. But it has a rendezvous with destiny.” At the time both Burman and Jackson were waiting for H-hour, 19-year-old Larry James, a Pathfinder for the 82 nd, was already moving silently behind the German lines in Normandy. Dropped at 11 : 07 pm from a bomber simulating a routine bombing over Normandy, he had been selected — with no choice and a 21-day training in a barbed-wired camp. A small vanguard of elite troops, the Pathfinders had to mark the dropping zones with « radar guns » for the next waves in the area of Sainte-Mère-Église. Behind them more than 1,200 aircraft would bear nearly 20,000 men into battle ; and behind them would come the gliders, for which the paratroopers would clear the way. As soon as the « radar guns » were placed, James crawled up to a promontory and took over a machine gun position to protect the 8-man « stick ». It was eerily quiet. All he could hear was a buddy of his whispering that he knew from a previous trip how great the welcome would be in France. The time they waited for the planes seemed like an eternity. Robert Burman, a veteran of Sicily and North Africa with the 507 th Parachute Infantry, had the precise task of landing west of the Merderet River. As soon as the unit could operate, he had to cut the enemy’s communications and set up roadblocks. But nothing happened the way they’d planned. When his plane reached the coast of France, heavy flak fire hit the plane, blowing such large holes through the fuselage, he says, “you could stick your head right through them.” The plane formation began to spread apart. And some pilots, most of whom had never seen a war, mistakenly gave the paratroopers the green light. Some dropped right into the ocean — to a certain death. Burman escaped that fate. But he landed far off course. At 2 : 00 am he landed east of the Merderet River instead of west. And the rest of the unit he was assigned to work with were nowhere to be seen. For at least three hours he waited alone. He mistook hedgerows for cows, and cows for German soldiers. And then he was no longer alone. But he was not with his mates. “All I could hear around me was a mechanized unit,” he recalls. “And I could hear all these Germans yelling. I tried to hide in the ditches on the sides of the roads.” To get away from the flak, some planes in the formation dove at least 100 feet. “You get quite a feeling in your stomach,” says Francis J. Duryer, then a 30-year-old paratrooper with the 505 th Parachute Infantry. “I was the last man to go out of the plane. We had some new fellows. So they put me back there to encourage them. I didn’t need to. They all did well. Upon hitting the ground, I saw a couple of parachute boots sticking out of the air. A fellow had been killed.” It was 2 : 00 am. “Scared French” at sunrise By Sunrise, Burman met a small group of paratroopers who had escaped the deadly swamps of the Merderet River, where two regiments of the 82 nd had landed. None of them could speak French. And the first French they came across were probably as scared as they were. “The French were hostile to us. A lot of them vanished,” he says. “This was primarily a dairy region, and the Germans were friendly with these people. They were living much better than the others. Of course, we were bombing their houses, setting fire to everything.” The group — all of them enlisted men — grew larger and larger. Finally it grew to around 300 under the command of General James M. Gavin, who’d dropped with them. They tried to get back to the main body, west of the river. But it took many hours — sometimes days — before each platoon became a fighting unit. In the meantime, half of Burman’s platoon — 36 soldiers — had been killed by sunset of that first day, including the priest and a chaplain. Andy Kilcullen’s squad also tried to get back to the assigned drop zone — eight miles away from the place where they’d actually landed. They never succeeded. At D-Day twilight, a group of German soldiers began shooting, killing 12 men. Kilcullen, a 22-year-old paratrooper with the 505 th Parachute Infantry Regiment, was captured and sent to a Nazi camp. (He escaped seven months later.) Describing himself as gung ho and a fighter whose mission was to kill as many Germans as possible, Burman won the Silver Star eight days after the invasion, when, under heavy fire, he « cleared » a bunch of houses of German snipers and machine gunners. But the war ended for him shortly after. In a short battle, eight members of his 12-man unit were killed by a German motor unit that had heavy automatic weapons. “I was hit in my shoulder and my neck, which completely paralyzed my left arm,” he says. “I was lying in a ditch. This German unit came down the road. And I could still see this German, with his fixed bayonet. He just came by me and gave me another stick in the chest. I passed out from the loss of blood.” Burman woke up in a medical unit, and was hospitalized in England for three months. Then he was sent back home to a neurological hospital in White Sulfur Springs, West Virginia. His wounds made him one of the few survivors of the 82 nd who did not take part in the 4-million-person Victory Parade in New York City on January 12, . As soon as Schuyler Jackson passed across the French coastline, his sole focus was to get out of the Carrier Troop Command plane. “I was scared and I was never so glad to get out of a plane, because you had all that ack-ack and shells coming up at you,” he says. “Every seventh one was a tracer. So there was a beautiful display, like fireworks. Then we jumped. Being the first wave, we had to jump very low — about 300 and 400 feet.” Jackson jumped, the fifth man out, with 100 pounds of equipment, including 15 pounds of high explosives, a string of detonation caps and $10 worth of new French money just minted in Washington for the invasion. They were in France, but at the wrong place. The 101 st Division was supposed to be controlling the Carentan- Montebourg-Cherbourg road in the area of Sainte-Mère-Église, but its men were isolated. Some of them mixed with the 82 nd Airborne. Others were scattered over an area 25 miles long by 15 miles wide — partly because a sudden wind had blown them apart. Their maps were too small to represent the entire area. So they were lost. It was a failed jump over an unknown country of hedgerows, deep gravel roads and grass fields. Yet, this incoherent scattering of men created such confusion among the German troops that it proved to be a remarkable act of war. Strange sounds in the Norman night The Norman night was filled with strange sounds. Every paratrooper was provided with a toy cricket whose telltale click-clack had to be answered two times. In some cases, however, the German rifles’clips made the same double sound, and the answer was a deadly shot. Daylight came, finally. A half-dozen colonels of the 101 st managed to take over groups of between 75 and 200 men. They passed through the first villages of Normandy. The first contacts with the French were rather unfriendly. A few waved and smiled, while many more kept their heads down and wouldn’t look up. “They were quite frightened,” says George B. Woldt, then a 33-year-old Second Lieutenant. “The situation seemed unpredictable. We could be here today, and tomorrow the Germans could be back. I suppose they were hesitant to become friendly with us.” But things were worse when they had to shoot French men and women who had collaborated with the Germans. These were bad memories that the veterans would rarely speak about. “You couldn’t tell who was who,” says Richard Ramsey, who was a 17-year-old paratrooper when he landed in Normandy before the invasion to contact the local resistance, went back to England and then was dropped on D-Day with the 502 nd Parachute Infantry. “You didn’t want to hurt anybody, until they wanted to hurt you. The ones I felt sorry for were the kids.” D-Day was a haze of violent action and confusion and, on top of it, there was a language problem. Although the soldiers had been briefed to avoid conversation with the French, many found they had no other way to get their questions answered. Jackson rushed into a farmhouse one morning and said to the old farmer : “Me  American, where Germans ?” The terrified Frenchman pointed across a field and, using the usual French term for German soldiers, shouted : “Boches ! Boches !” “To hell with the Boches !” Jackson replied, “Where are the Germans ?”Paratrooper Dave Jackendoff, although wounded, was one of the more fortunate D-Day survivors. He may even have been, as his sergeant later claimed, “the healthiest guy of the division.” At 33, he was the oldest, a technician 5th grade, but also the most undisciplined. Turned down by the Marines for being too old, Jackendoff had volunteered for the new 101 stDivision and had been admitted in the 502 nd Parachute Infantry at the beginning of the war. In Normandy, he revealed himself a pretty good combat soldier and an excellent combat pitcher with hand grenades. Most of all, he proved to be an ingenious Yankee. “Nobody knew where we were, except me,” he says, with no hint of pride. “I had stolen a silk handkerchief from the officers’quarters with a map of Normandy. I knew exactly our battalion’s mission, which was to get four German 155’s [155mm Howitzer guns], which were looking right down on Utah Beach, where the 4 th Division would land in the morning.” The handkerchief revealed itself to be a good guide. As soon as daylight arrived, his group found a farmhouse. He saw a jug in a sink. “I started washing my face with what I thought was water,” he says, “and my head started bleeding. It tickled my nose. I said, ’Fellas, this is booze.’ I started drinking it. I said, ’This is good booze !’ I filled up my two canteens with it. Four days later, when I came back to my battalion, my sergeant told me that he was going to give me the Purple Heart. I said, ’Doc, please don’t. Nobody shot me. I am in good shape, don’t worry.’ He said, ’What have you done ?’ I said. ’I have been washing the wounds with this stuff in my canteen.’ And I took a swig. He said, ’What have you got there ?’ ’I don’t know, Doc. It’s whisky.’ He said, ’You know what you’ve been drinking ? That’s Calvados, the Normandy apple brandy.’ And I’ve been drinking Calvados ever since.” Utah Beach, shortly before 6 AM H-hour on Utah Beach, on the western coast of the Cotentin Peninsula, was scheduled to be at 6 : 30 am. However, along the invasion beaches tidal variations dictated four different H-hours from Utah Beach to Sword Beach — a span of one hour and 25 minutes. Shortly before 6 am, 865 vessels started battering the beach and blowing up the German pillboxes. Some 276 aircraft of the US 9 th Air Force roared in over the beach defenses, delivering a total of 4,404 bombs, each of them 250 pounds. A first wave of soldiers came, transported by the LCT’s, weighed down by equipment. Some were blown up in the explosion of land mines. Despite this, the troops successfully advanced. A second wave came to clear passages. There were bulldozers on their crafts along with special units of engineers. Wave after wave followed. Utah Beach became the first stronghold of the Allied Forces. By noon, the beach had been cleared at a cost of 197 men killed — far fewer than on Omaha Beach. Soldiers were able to make contact with paratroopers from the 101 st Airborne Division, who had dropped behind enemy lines before dawn. Robert E. Kaufman landed unarmed, but he wore around his belt a bag filled with morphine syringes, sulpha powder, bandages and tourniquets. A 36-year-old doctor with the 22 nd Regiment’s medical team, he hit the Utah beach at 10 : 30 am, just in time to see General Teddy Roosevelt walking nonchalantly along the beach with a swagger stick and waving to his men to go across the beach. Kaufman moved with the 4 th Division frontline and treated the wounded as soon as he could, giving them a shot of morphine and covering them with blankets. But most of the wounded from the 101 stneeded to be rapidly evacuated to better-equipped medical units. Ironically, the first field hospital was a German bunker — a few miles inland. The enemy was so surprised by the airborne night attack, Kaufman says, that cards and drinks were still on the table. Many of these bunkers had two levels, so that a large number of wounded could be laid down. However, the ceiling was so low that the wounded had to be carried outside in order to receive plasma. Woldt, a 101 st Second Lieutenant of the 327 th Glider Infantry, recalls that on the day after the invasion, Utah Beach was already used to gather the wounded paratroopers from the interior. “They were lined up behind a sand dune,” he says. “As we landed and got off the ships, they were going back on the ships.” For him and the men of the E Company, which landed on D-Day + 1, it was an introduction to real war. “We’d had training and practice, but there were no enemies. Here, we knew that their job was to kill us, our job was to kill them.” Omaha Beach : “Bodies as far as your eyes could see” On the edge of a sparsely populated region, Omaha Beach was a long arc of sand from which rose small gently sloping cliffs leading to a plateau where fields enclosed by hedges and hamlets built solidly in stone were scattered. Out of 90 seaside villas that stood down the plateau before the war, there were now only seven. The German troops had destroyed them to reinforce the coastal front and install a giant network of mines. They had spiders — made of railroad iron and standing shoulder-high just beneath the surface of the water during high tide. They also buried huge logs in the sand, pointing upward and outward. Attached to the logs were mines. Moreover, new troops — the Wehrmacht’s 352 nd Infantry Division — had just come and strengthened defensive positions by trenches linking pillboxes and by gun emplacements laterally sited to bring devastating crossfire upon the beach. Invasion plans for Omaha had been carefully scheduled. The first men to hit the beach would have to be inland within a matter of minutes, attacking gun positions from behind. Schedules would call for engineers to land at H-hour plus 2 minutes. Even the press censors would land at H-hour plus 75 minutes. But the schedule didn’t come close to holding. Despite a continuous naval bombardment, the small landing craft rarely reached the assigned zones of debarkation. They were exposed to the full force of the north westerly winds, fighting seas up to six feet high and taking on water too fast for the pumps. The so-called DD tanks, specially adapted for amphibious service, were launched too far away from the shore — and sank. Two of them managed to reach the beach, only to serve as a desperate shelter for the 300 men who had succeeded in hitting the edge of the tide. Most drowned before they got there, awkward in their heavy equipment, when their LCTs were gored and they foundered under the enemy’s artillery. In a macabre display, the tide pushed their bodies toward the beach as though they were determined to join their fellow fighting men. There was no assault. Within a half-hour, the 1,000 infantrymen and engineers alive on the beach were fighting for survival, exhausted and too weary to drag their equipment across the beach to attack the enemy. Some went back to the water, looking for the meager shelter of the sea wall, the swamped bodies and the burning crafts. Bill Fleiss came with the third wave, at H-hour plus 30 minutes. A veteran of Tunisia and Sicily with the 16th regiment of the 1 stDivision, he felt confident. Morale was sensational, after General Eisenhower had talked to each of the regiments in England. Fleiss’s group was to rendezvous in the water. “I was in an LCT with about 50 people. But we were kidding and joking,” he says, “Then bullets were hitting the water in front of us. There were 88 [cm anti- aircraft and anti-tank flak] shells coming down and hitting soldiers and boats. I ran up to the beach, pretty frightened at this point. We were on the left, Omaha Red. The soldiers of the first and the second waves hadn’t gone on about 20 feet. Everybody was just there. They fell where they landed.” There was no room for patriotism and grandiose feelings. “You were doing a very dirty job in a very horrible situation,” says Fleiss, then a 23-year-old Corporal, “You had to do your job and just hope to survive.” Demolition men played a central role. Coming in on the heels of the assault infantry, they had to clear the paths through the beach. Each of the 16 teams trained for its specially role in its sector, but only five came near to their assignments. And of these, three were utterly alone, unprotected by man or gun, naked to the enemy. Leading one of these teams was 24-year-old Lieutenant Walter Sidlowski, of the 348 thEngineer Combat Battalion. At about 9 : 30 am, his unit landed 500 yards away from its assigned zone. He had a big toothache — an exposed nerve — and no fear of death. “We moved laterally, close the beach, to the left. We made the 500 yards by crawling, running, crawling again, dropping behind burned-out tanks,” he says. “Germans hit us with direct fire. They knew who we were. Their primary targets were the bulldozers that were supposed to push aside the obstacles. And they knew that everybody who was around the bulldozers were engineers.” Sidlowski finally reached the assigned zone. Today he remembers clearIy what he saw. “The beach was murky. To the right of us, there was a landing craft that had two half-tracks [armored personnel carriers] that were exploding and burning. There were some people in muddy dress that were yelling, calling for aid. The tide was already covering many small vehicles, ammunition, stuff like that. Soldiers were mixed up, from different units. And there was that acrid smell that I will never forget.” As one officer said, the only way to take a beach is to face it and keep going. Otherwise soldiers are pinned down, then pushed back to the waves behind them where they might stay for years. By nightfall, the Germans had lost the strong positions over the dunes, and thousands of US soldiers — probably unaware of the possibility of victory — kept on going, foot by foot. But for their success, there was a price to be paid. “A week after D-Day, I went back to Omaha Beach” says paratrooper Burman, “It was unbelievable. Bodies as far as your eyes could see. Just to look at it, it made you deadly sick.” In the first 24 hours of the invasion, 1,456 Americans died, most of them on Omaha Beach ; 3,184 were wounded ; 1,928 were listed as missing ; and 26 were captured by the enemy. Walter Sidlowski survived. From the pocket guide to France, he had learned that he would probably “get a big welcome from the French,” because it was assumed that “Americans are popular in France.” He  kept  on repeating one of the only sentences that he remembered from his high school French class. “Voulez-vous danser avec moi, ce soir ? ” — which was not included in the booklet. However, his first date was rather disappointing. As he was still clearing the minefields on Omaha Beach, a French official came by and asked if all the mines would be removed before the tourist season. He said that a lot of people would come for lobsters. Sidlowski had no pat answer. But he was already thinking of the famous Folies Bergères cabaret shows. He would be “Un Américain à Paris.” When the news came to New York Never was such big news heard by so few. Reuters was the first to flash « Invasion begun — Germans Overseas News Agency » at 6 : 33 am, London time, claiming a two-minute beat. That the first flash actually came from the enemy was amazing, since the German officials took so much time to believe in the invasion of Normandy and to react to it. The official news came hours later, at exactly 9 : 32 am, when Eisenhower’s press officer released a 26-word communiqué in the crowded press room of the War Ministry in London. Within a minute after he said, « Gentlemen, this is the communiqué that we have all been waiting for » six background stories were released while the journalists were rushing to their offices. The Reuters flash hit a sleepy New York. Transmitted by the Associated Press, the bells tinkled at exactly 12 : 37 am, local time. Four hours later came the first eyewitness account by NBC’s Wright Bryan, who had flown over the invasion coast with paratroopers and breathlessly spoke from a London broadcast studio. In the meantime, CBS anchorman Bob Trout kept on speaking for seven hours, reading dispatches as they came in and letting his listeners hear the tickers ticking and the chairs shuffling. It was a wonderful June morning in Manhattan. It was Tuesday and the sun rose at 4 : 24. Gene Mc- Dermott, a 19- year-old Private on Army leave, was sleeping soundly after a late beer party. At 9 : 00 am, his father came running into his bedroom. “The boys just landed in France,”  he said. Mc- Dermott stood up quickly. “I’ll be next,”  he told his father. He was there, 90 days after D-Day. Across the country, generally the mood was solemn. Time magazine wrote in its June 12 issue, “There was no sudden fear, as on that September morning in  when the Germans marched into Poland ; no sudden hate, as on Pearl Harbor day. This time, moved by a common impulse, the casual churchgoers as well as the devout went to pray.” The invasion was long-awaited news. Papers and magazines had been filled with ads related to a possible “beach- head invasion.” As early as May 29, a Camel advertisement was headlined “Hit that Beach !” Two GIs were pictured smoking cigarettes that “are packed to go round the world.” European kids will never forget Camel cigarettes, chewing gum and chocolates as a symbol of the American forces who arrived on June 6,  to free them from the Nazi regime and the harshness of the war. West Point, 40 years after the war Four candles were burning — each one in honor of those who died during the 101 stAirborne’s four major battles, including the first : Normandy. Four West Point cadets came in, announced by drum rolls. In a mechanical move, they toured the large dining room holding the Stars and Stripes, breaking the eerie silence by their rhythmic march. A bugle call demanded respect for the dead. The many flags and regiments’emblems almost quivered. Despite the years since World War II, some veterans kept their heads down so that nobody could see their tears. Yet, after Colonel Robert E. Jones, a retired officer who serves as a National Vice President for the 101st Airborne Division  Association,  told  the  veterans  that  “wars  are  not  won  by  the  casualties  we  sustained  but  by  the survivors,” the dining room of the West Point Thayer Hotel refilled with exclamations and excitement. It sounded as if the war had never ended. For most attending the memorial dinner, it was a time to share memories in total privacy. Crude accounts of the war were kept secret, even from wives and close friends. They had not dropped in the same foxholes. They did not see a fellow crying for medical emergency, giving a last outcry and then softly dying. They did not kill either, says Richard Ramsey. “If you had a close friend run to you and die in your arms, would you want to talk about that ?” he asks. Most veterans simply never talked about the war outside the service. They decided to say nothing as soon as they got home. A month after the war, Bill Fleiss took a girl to a party. “The girl presented me to a couple and showed my decorations,” says Fleiss, then a retired stockbroker in New York. “They just started talking about my honors. I thought to myself, ’Don’t try to make a trade on this. It’s over, over.’” So the Normandy veterans kept it to themselves, feeling too distant from those who stayed at home or even with the many soldiers who never get involved in combat. Says Jackendoff : “One out of six soldiers is a combat man. It takes five men to keep one man fighting. It takes five men to keep him supplied with ammunition, with food, with all that a fighting man needs. And very often we ran short.” Veterans at that West Point ceremony said they feel alienated from today’s younger generation. And the feeling seems mutual. Their younger counterparts don’t seem to understand the war generation. They never experienced the war, or the Nazi occupation. To the older veterans, they are unpatriotic and, most of all, they have forgotten the historical basis of the freedom that they enjoy. “They just walk in the streets,” says Burman, “with no regard for the fact that people have died, have given their lives to allow the freedom in this country today.” It’s a different kind of world and warfare, the veterans said. There is no more pride in wearing the uniform. The country passed through the Vietnam War. Young people have turned off and even their kids don’t want to hear about what their fathers did. As a result, World War II souvenirs and decorations remained for years in boxes, and nobody at home even knew where that box was. At the West Point ceremony, there was a strong feeling that the United States should continue defending its own borders by fighting abroad. “We always felt that the war over there was our own war,” says Georges B. Woldt, “because if Hitler had been successful in Europe, the next step would have been over here.” To  young Americans reluctant to fight overseas, the veterans’message is : “If you don’t fight there, you’ll be fighting here.” “Perhaps we live in memories of what we did,” concludes Dave Jackendoff, nervously scratching a plastic glass filled with Calvados. But “we are very proud of what we did,” he adds. “I am. And so are all my friends.” Christophe Lamfalussy is a Brussels-based journalist and author who has covered international affairs and wars for 35 years. He reported for the daily La Libre Belgique from Bosnia and Kosovo, Afghanistan, Iraq, Syria, Armenia and Africa. In addition, he focused on terrorism after September 11, . He co-authored several books, including two on Belgian jihadists involved in the Paris and Brussels attacks. Ouest-France / Thomas Brégardis', " That a four-year programme is yet to end 10 years after for our cadets in The Philippines only reflects bad governance at the home front. When a public official like the Minister of Information and Culture, Lai Mohammed, accuses the Nigerian media of lack of patriotism for concentrating on the negative aspects of the country in their reports, he forgets incidents such as the one we are going to look at today in this column. By the way, where is Mr Mohammed? He appears to have gone into hibernation. Or is he on sabbatical or something? Whichever it is, whoever knows where he is should extend my sincere greetings to him. As we say, 'long time no see, long time no hear from him'. I miss him a lot. I am sure millions of Nigerians miss him as well. He too must be missing us. As I was saying, Nigerian public officials who accuse the media of lack of patriotism because of the negative stories about Nigeria that dominate the media space often forget two things; first that the world is now a global village and second, some of these unsavoury developments about Mr. Mohammed's beloved government and country happen outside the country, which make it impossible for them to be swept under the carpet. Take for instance, the pathetic case of 117 Nigerian students in The Philippines who have spent 10 years for a programme  that  should  last  four  years.  I  am  talking  about  the  hapless  beneficiaries  of  the  Nigerian  Seafarers Development Programme (NSDP) whose story went virile in a video shared on Twitter a few days ago. They were in The Phillipines to study Marine Engineering and Transportation under the NIMASA-NSDP scholarship. The NSDP, an initiative of the Nigerian Maritime Administration and Safety Agency (NIMASA) commenced in . It was basically designed to address the shortage of trained and certified seafarers in the Nigerian maritime industry. A good initiative, if you ask me. But Nigeria is never short of good initiatives. The problem is that they mess up the initiatives almost as soon as the ink that was used to draft them dries up on paper. Civil servants and politicians in no time corrupt the process for personal gains. Otherwise, why would an initiative that began in  start having hiccups barely three years after? These students must have leapt for joy when they began the programme in . Little did they know that that was going to be the beginning of a 10-year sojourn in a foreign land. Never would they have imagined that cash would be their problem, given the fact that the sponsor of the scholarship, NIMASA, is a cash cow that is capable of rendering surplus funds to government coffers as we witnessed some years ago. So, money would not have been its problem; if it had any problem, it is probably how to spend it. And we have seen evidence of that irony in its handling of the case of these cadets. It was when the cadets were pushed to the wall, as it were, that they decided to protest at the Nigerian Embassy in Manila, that country's capital. They were however not allowed to do what one of them called 'simple demonstration'. Security personnel were brought in to prevent them from entering the embassy. One of them said rather pathetically, that 'This has lasted for 10 good years, I have wasted my life, 10 years of my life and many of my colleagues also in this same programme. Now finally we are here for the last lap where we would get our license and go back to Nigeria, yet...' Read Also: Awaiting deployment of NIMASA's N50b Modular Floating Dock But some of the students saw the 'Nigerian factor' coming early enough and quickly jumped off the NIMASA boat. Indeed, one of such persons, Abraham Samuel, who reacted to the video lamented that 'a programme that began in , 10 years later people are still languishing and suffering at home. I for one can say that NIMASA failed in making the programme a success, most of the persons in The Philippines are self-sponsored and only because they got tired of waiting for NIMASA and had to look for every means possible to kickstart their lives; I am one of such people.' The embassy's response to all of this was an epistle that explained little or nothing. It accused the students of being unruly. As a matter of fact, the embassy's defence of its uncaring attitude towards the cadets can be summarised in two sentences: first the students did not book an appointment with it before staging their peaceful demonstration and two, they did not obtain the necessary permission from that country's authorities as demanded by their laws before embarking on the protest. The embassy that is supposed to be the ears and eyes of the Nigerian government said in a statement that 'And as such, the Estate/ Barangay reserves the right to prohibit persons from entering the premises without an appointment.' It added that policemen came into the picture because 'the unruly cadets were disturbing the peace of the residents in the area and obstructing vehicular traffic.' The embassy added that its officials went to meet with the 'defiant cadets' at the entrance of the estate to listen to their complaints 'which were delivered in a very insulting and demeaning manner with no regard for the government of the Federal Republic of Nigeria on whose sponsorship they were in The Philippines in the first place.' Pray, has the Nigerian government itself not insulted the students and dehumanised them by making them embark on what was worse than the Israelites' journey? Or how does one explain that a four-year programme would last a whole decade? Not even Medicine would have taken them such a long period to learn. If the Nigerian government had not advertised scholarship for the programme, those of the students interested in the course would have entered as private students and if they did not have the means, they would at least have remained in their own country where it is possible for a four-year academic programme to drag for eight or more years. They would not have to face such dehumanisation outside Nigeria. In summary, the embassy's response to the students' plight was as sad as it was disturbing. It was most disgusting. No empathy. Not even an enemy camp would have been more callous. How many of the embassy officials' children were involved in the peculiar mess? Put differently, how many of their children ever experienced such inhuman and ungodly treatment? These are people who, like the embassy officials' children, have a future ahead of them. That the embassy used the word 'unruly' at least twice in its statement to describe the students' attitude shows how rude and unruly the embassy itself is. It makes one to ask whether these are career diplomats or the officials are the usual Nigerian 'job-for-the-boys' round pegs in square holes personnel. But the Nigerian embassy in The Philippines is not alone in this shabby treatment of their compatriots. We are constantly inundated with similar reports from many of our embassies, whether in Africa or outside the continent. What many of the embassies have done is export the uncaring and insensitive style of government at home, abroad. If the home government is bad, such can only rub off on its adjuncts wherever they may be. Given the import of the principle of extraterritoriality in international relations, the embassies are extensions of the Nigerian space. May be that explains their replication of the bad governance at home, abroad! For sure, the embassy in The Philippines cannot say it was not aware of the cadets' pathetic story before the last incident that went viral. The cadets had in August complained bitterly of neglect and non-payment of their allowances, hence they were unable to pay their rent or meet other obligations. In view of our experiences in other Nigerian embassies abroad, it is not unlikely that the cadets had communicated with the embassy on their proposed peaceful protest without having any response. It is now that the matter has become a national embarrassment that NIMASA too says it would send a fact-finding team to The Philippines to monitor the unfortunate development. Every Nigerian who understands the mystery of our kind of governance knew this would be the next step. The fact-finding team would have to get estacode and other perks, avoidable costs if things had been allowed to run normally. Then their findings would be reviewed by another high-powered committee and so on. Even in the days when foreign students were still coming to study in Nigerian universities on scholarship, I cannot remember the number of times such fact-finding teams were sent to Nigeria from those countries despite the fact that they did not have the advantage of information technology that has simplified virtually everything we do today. Is NIMASA saying it does not have a record of what has been paid so far for each of the students and what they are owing? Again, why would the agency be talking as if it does not know that governance is a continuum? Or, what does it mean by 'the matter predates this administration?' It is rather unfortunate that the bread that the Nigerian government had asked these cadets to come and take has turned to stone and the fish turned to serpent, in contradiction of the Holy Writ, by this uncaring attitude, which is common with many Nigerian students on government scholarship. No serious nation would do such to people it considers its future leaders. Why would youths bubbling with ideas have to grow grey hairs and moustache before finishing a four-year programme? The unfortunate thing is that despite the embarrassment that this matter has caused Nigeria, chances are that those responsible would go scot-free. This is the kind of experience that had led some stranded Nigerian female students to take to prostitution abroad while the males among them had turned to crime, jeopardising their health and future in the process. It would seem the Buhari administration has developed thick skin to anything called national embarrassment which  naturally  should  warrant  strong  punishment.  This  is  why  there  can  never  be  an  end  to  such  humiliating embarrassment. But we would continue to sit on a keg of gunpowder for as long as we keep treating matters like this with kid gloves. The anti-corruption agencies must wade into the matter. We need to establish that some people are not feeding fat on these cadets' misery. Such a thing cannot be ruled out in our kind of country where the dog knows how to feed its puppies but won't hesitate to sink their canines into others'.", ' Notting Hill flat; John Christie had framed his neighbour for the murder of his wife but was later caught and executed. By, Holly Evans Byline: By, Holly Evans While there have been a number of vicious serial killers to have walked the streets of London, one of the most horrifying series of murders occurred in the now-affluent area of Notting Hill during the s. On a quiet morning in March, a gruesome discovery was made of three dead women hidden behind the wallpaper of a flat on Number 10 Rillington Place. This later led to further discoveries of bodies hidden in the back garden, with the former occupant of the flat, John Christie, going on the run until he was eventually caught by a police officer. Known as Reg to his friends, the terrifying serial killer strangled at least eight people at his flat in Notting Hill, including his own wife and his neighbour\'s wife and baby. This led to the wrongful conviction of Timothy Evans, who was framed for murdering his wife and child and was later hanged. READ MORE: Gruesome murder of London banker found decomposed in a plastic bag 4 months after being dumped in river remains unsolved Who was John Christie After admitting his gruesome crimes, he was tried for the murder of his wife Ethel. Despite pleading insanity, with his defence lawyer saying he was "mad as a March hare" he was found guilty after just 85 minutes of deliberation from the jury. He was later hanged by the same executioner who had previously hanged Evans. Born near Halifax in Yorkshire, Christie was raised in a troubled household and was the sixth in a family of seven children. His father was an austere, emotionless man who would punish his children for the most trivial of offences. Meanwhile he was coddled by his overbearing mother, which led him to become sexually dysfunctional with a dislike for women. In March , his granddad died and his body was laid out on a table in the house. Christie later said that seeing the body gave him a sense of power and well-being, as the man he once feared was now reduced to a corpse. It was during his teenage years that he first began to struggle with impotence, and his first failed sexual exploits earned him the nickname \'Can\'t-Do-It-Christie\' among his peers. Throughout his life, he could only perform with prostitutes  and  was  impotent  with  his  wife  Ethel.  Despite  this,  a  post-mortem  examination  found  no  physical explanation for his impotence. During the First World War, he was enlisted in the British Army and was later injured in a mustard gas attack. He later claimed that this attack had rendered him mute and blind for three years, however psychologists believe this stemmed from an underlying personality disorder that made him feign illness to get attention. In , he married Ethel Simpson, a woman from Bradford, yet he continued to visit prostitutes. Their marriage was not successful, and they separated after four years, although they later reunited in  and she moved into 10 Rillington Place. Meanwhile Christie embarked on a life of petty crime, and served a number of small prison sentences for theft, assault and violent conduct. While working as a postman, he was jailed for stealing postal orders and was later jailed again for obtaining money on false pretences. After he was eventually released, he and Ethel moved into the flat where he would later go on to commit his atrocious crimes. At the time, Notting Hill was a run-down area of London with a number of the properties inhabited by multi- occupancy rentals. Living conditions were described as "squalid" and none of the flats had a bathroom. His first murders Over a 10-year period, Christie murdered eight women, usually by strangling his victims after he had rendered them unconscious  with  domestic  gas.  His  first  victim  was  Ruth  Fuerst,  a  21-year-old  Austrian  munitions  worker  that occasionally engaged in prostitution. After inviting her back to his home on August 24, , he impulsively strangled her on his bed with a piece of rope. He initially placed her body beneath the floorboards of his living room but then buried it in the back garden the following evening, before his wife returned from visiting relatives. Soon afterwards, he began to work as a clerk at a radio factory in Acton and met his second victim who was a colleague. On October 7, , he invited Muriel Eady back to his flat with the promise that he had concocted a "special mixture" to cure her bronchitis. After handing her a jar with a tube, he instructed her to take deep breaths of the mixture. While her back was turned, he connected the tube to a gas tap, rendering her unconscious and allowing him to rape and strangle her, before burying her next to Fuerst in the garden. Neighbour from hell During the Easter of , Timothy Evans and his pregnant wife Beryl moved into the flat above Christie and his wife. Their daughter Geraldine was born shortly after, but by late , both were dead. Evans had informed the police that his wife was dead, with a police search revealing the bodies of Beryl, Geraldine and a 16-week male foetus in an outdoor wash-house. A post-mortem examination found that both mother and daughter had been strangled and that Beryl had been viciously assaulted before her death. Despite accusing Christie of their murders, Evans was put on trial for their murders and was found guilty by the jury. The prosecution called on Christie as a chief witness, and he gave detailed evidence about the quarrels between his neighbour and his late wife, which later helped secure a conviction. He was hanged at HMP Pentonville on March 9, . It later emerged that the police had made numerous mistakes in their handling of the investigation, particularly overlooking the remains of Christie\'s other victims who were buried in the garden. The twisted killer later revealed that a femur had been propped up on a fence and that his dog had later unearthed Eady\'s skull shortly after the police search. Three years passed and Christie managed to keep his murderous tendencies at bay. However, on December 14, , he strangled his wife  Ethel  in  their  bed and concocted a  series  of  elaborate  lies  to prevent  her  relatives  from discovering her fate. In a letter, he told her family in Sheffield that she had rheumatism and was unable to write, and went on to see her clothes and forge her signature to empty her bank account. His last three victims met their fate between January 19 and March 6, , after he gassed them to the point of unconsciousness, raped them and strangled them. Kathleen Maloney was a prostitute that he had met in Ladbroke Grove, while Rita Nelson was visiting her sister when she encountered Christie and was lured back to his flat. Tragically, she was six months pregnant at the time. His final victim was Hectorina MacLennan, who he met in a cafe with her boyfriend. The trio became friends and he allowed them to stay at his place in Notting Hill while they searched for their own accommodation. On an occasion where  she  was  alone,  he  murdered  her  and  later  convinced  her  boyfriend  that  he  had  no  knowledge  of  her whereabouts. He then stowed the last three bodies in a small alcove behind the back kitchen wall, which he later covered with wallpaper. Just two weeks later, he moved out of his flat and bizarrely began subletting it to another couple. His landlord visited and demanded that they leave, and then allowed another tenant to use Christie\'s kitchen. It was while trying to insert brackets in the wall to hold a wireless set that Beresford Brown made the gruesome discovery of the three bodies on March 24. The police were informed and a citywide manhunt ensued to capture the killer. After realising that his crimes had been uncovered, Christie left his hotel in King\'s Cross and spent several days sleeping rough, until he was recognised near Putney Bridge by a police officer. Among his possessions that he had upon him was an old newspaper clipping about the remand of Timothy Evans. While he initially only admitted to the murders of the women in the alcove and his wife during police questioning, he later admitted responsibility for the skeletons in the garden. He admitted killing Beryl but denied his responsibility in the murder of Geraldine, although he later confessed to a hospital orderly. He was only tried for the murder of his wife as he had pleaded on the grounds of insanity, but this was rejected by the jury and he was sentenced to death. He was hanged at 9am on July 15, , within the prison walls. His executioner was Albert Pierrepoint, the same man who had previously hanged Timothy Evans just a few years previously. After arriving at the gallows, Christie allegedly complained that his nose itched, to which Pierrepoint chillingly responded: "It won\'t bother you for long". He was later buried in an unmarked grave, while Rillington Place was renamed to distance itself from the horrors of his actions. Credit: (Photo by [c] Hulton-Deutsch Collection/CORBIS/Corbis via Getty Images) A police officer carries a bundle of bones, wrapped in newspaper, to a waiting police van outside 10, Rillington Place, London. The bones are those of the fifth person to be killed by the serial murderer John Reginald Christie, former resident of the property.', ' Radio-Canada John Paul Tasker  · CBC News International students are not required to get police certificates from law enforcement in their home countries before coming to Canada — something critics say needs to change. People applying for permanent residency, citizenship or International Experience Canada (commonly known as the working holiday visa)  are required to produce such police certificates  , which give Canadian officials early warning of an applicant\'s possible criminal history in their country of origin. But Canadian visa officers don\'t necessarily have access to police-drafted documents when deciding whether to admit an international student. A spokesperson for Immigration, Refugees and Citizenship Canada (IRCC) told CBC News that all officials screen applications from all over the world for inadmissibility in order to maintain the security of Canadians. Immigration  officials  work  with  law  enforcement  partners  like  the  RCMP  to  carry  out  a  comprehensive  security screening to help identify those who might pose a threat to Canadians, the spokesperson said. That screening process may involve a criminal history check, or require students to submit biometrics like fingerprints and photos, the spokesperson added. That\'s not enough, said P.E.I. Sen. Percy Downe, who previously served as chief of staff to former Liberal prime minister Jean Chrétien. He\'s become an advocate for more stringent security checks since an international student working at an office supply store in Charlottetown  sexually assaulted a local woman. Downe maintains that all international students should be required to provide a police certificate so Canada can avoid inadvertently admitting someone with a criminal past. Officials shouldn\'t simply request police certificates on a case-by-case basis, he said, because that could allow bad actors to slip through the cracks, especially when the IRCC is dealing with such a high volume of would-be students. We need to make sure that everybody coming in, regardless of where in the world they\'re coming from, is subjected to some sort of security check. We don\'t need to import any more criminals. We have enough of our own, Downe told CBC News. We need to make sure the people coming are not only safe for Canadians here but also for the other international students — they also want a safe environment. The number of international students with active study permits in Canada rose to 1,040,985 in , a 195 per cent increase over the 352,305 who were here in  when the Liberal government was first elected, according to IRCC  data. While the government said last fall it would  tighten admissability rules for international students,   numbers tabled in Parliament show the number of people here on study permits actually increased to 1,073,435 as of May 31. The federal government has since said it will  put limits on the program   but IRCC is still planning to issue about 485,000 new study permits for this academic year and 437,000 for the next. Canada further reducing the number of international student permits International students are a major economic driver, providing hundreds of millions of dollars in tuition for the country\'s universities and colleges. Ottawa\'s recent move to rein in the number of international students has faced  a lot of pushback  from the institutions that depend on these newcomers. The explosive growth in the number of international students has helped  prop up colleges and universities that are facing a decline  in domestic enrolment and dramatic provincial  funding cuts. WATCH: Universities, colleges say foreign student cuts could hurt Canada\'s reputation Researchers from McGill University have said there\'s  no strong evidence  to suggest immigration causes crime rates to increase. International students are not classified by the federal government as immigrants, although many do apply for permanent residency after their studies. Statistics Canada, which maintains a database of police-reported crime, does not collect any data relating to the citizenship of alleged criminals, a spokesperson for the agency told CBC News. The  Canada  Border  Services  Agency  (CBSA)  does  have  some  data  on  how  many  foreign  nationals,  including international students, have been removed from this country because of criminal matters. In , 511 people were given a removal order (commonly known as deportation), according to data provided to CBC News. Of that number, 390 were removed for what the CBSA calls serious criminality. The numbers are already higher this year, with 568 removals in the first nine months of  — 418 of them for serious criminal acts. Those figures give an incomplete picture because some criminally convicted foreign nationals are able to successfully appeal a removal order and remain in the country. International students have been accused of carrying out some serious crimes in Canada. An international student was accused of  murdering six people  — four children and two adults — in suburban Ottawa earlier this year. In Sudbury, Ont., an international student  pleaded guilty   to manslaughter last year after killing a classmate over a marijuana-related dispute. Sources have told CBC News one of the suspects accused of gunning down B.C. Sikh temple leader Hardeep Singh Nijjar was  an international student. Immigration Minister Marc Miller has said the foreign national accused last month of plotting a terror attack on Jewish sites in New York City was in Canada as  an international student. Two years ago, a UPEI international student pleaded guilty to sexually assaulting a customer at a Charlottetown Staples store. International students have also been arrested for  voyeurism ,  vandalism  and  fraud. Dreams of studying in Canada fade for students in India Non-permanent residents unfairly blamed for poor government planning, say protesters CBSA told CBC News it is investigating 285 current and former international students suspected of fraud for using phoney post-secondary acceptance letters to take advantage of Canada\'s immigration system. About 28 people, some of whom were involved in organized crime, have been removed or have left the country voluntarily as CBSA continues to investigates the fraud, the agency said. Alberta Conservative MP Tom Kmiec is the party\'s immigration critic. He said the Liberals have torpedoed the longstanding Canadian consensus that welcoming more newcomers is a good thing. The concern I hear the most, and it\'s one I share as an immigrant myself, is that the Liberals have undermined public confidence in the system, he told CBC News. "We\'ve got to make sure we know who these people are when they\'re entering the country and that nobody is being defrauded. A police background check — that should be part of the basics. I don\'t understand why the government wouldn\'t make it a mandatory step. It\'s common sense. Frankly, it\'s a privilege to come to Canada. We have an amazing country. At a minimum we should ask these students for a police record check, That\'s what Canadians expect. Kmiec said it wouldn\'t be a burdensome requirement because the study permit application process is all digital. It\'s just uploading another PDF document. Extra information is never a bad thing, especially when you\'re protecting Canadians and residents who are already here from people who might have an ulterior motive, he said. Dale McCartney is an assistant professor at the University of the Fraser Valley who studies the international student program. He said it\'s reasonable to worry about crime but he questions whether the government can do much about it through police certificates. Practically speaking, I don\'t know if we can eliminate crime. If people are coming to Canada to possibly murder people — aren\'t those people going to lie? Aren\'t they going to manufacture the documents they need? Isn\'t that a relatively straightforward process? I doubt this would be super effective, he said in an interview. That\'s the argument Miller himself made before a Commons committee last month. We rely on our security partners to advise us as to the risk profile to take with respect to these individuals, the minister told MPs. There are questions around the validity and the reliability of those certificates. McCartney said there\'s also a risk these security checks could be unevenly applied and become corrupted by anti- Black and anti-South Asian racism and Islamophobia. He also said international students face a huge crisis of exploitation because they tend to be unfamiliar with Canada. He said acts of abuse, assault and mistreatment targeting international students are rampant. It\'s incredibly destructive and it\'s very hard to track down. McCartney called for better settlement support programs for visiting students, like those offered to some asylum- seekers and refugees. Many international students don\'t know how to protect themselves because they don\'t have the local knowledge that many Canadians take for granted, he said. Universities and colleges are not prepared for this at all. There\'s  extensive  evidence  of  international  students  being  victims  of  crimes,  including  abuse  by  fraudsters, blackmailers and  criminally negligent landlords. Some students have been targeted for prostitution and have been  sexually assaulted. There has been  a surge in hate crimes   in some places, most notably in Ontario\'s Waterloo region, which officials attribute to the increase in international students. The Indian government is also raising red flags about the number of its citizens dying while in Canada. More than 170 of them have died here over the last five years, according to India\'s external affairs department — a figure higher than the one reported in the U.S. and nearly triple the number of Indian student deaths in Australia and the U.K. in the same time period. He is also a regular panellist on CBC News Network\'s Power & Politics.
